summary: This is an email chain from September 6, 2019, discussing the release of Jeffrey Epstein's autopsy report by the Office of the Chief Medical Examiner (OCME) to his brother, Mark Epstein. The emails detail the U.S. Attorney's Office's request for redactions to protect sensitive information related to the ongoing criminal investigation into Epstein's death at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC).

persons.name: Mark Epstein
persons.role: Jeffrey Epstein's brother and next of kin
persons.context: He is the next of kin to whom the OCME plans to release Jeffrey Epstein's redacted autopsy report.

persons.name: Lt. M
persons.role: MCC guard on duty when Epstein's body was found
persons.context: A key MCC witness interviewed by the FBI; a draft FBI 302 of this interview was provided to OCME and is among the materials requested to be redacted.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the autopsy report; his death by suicide at MCC is the focus of the ongoing investigation.

connections.description: Mark Epstein is identified as Jeffrey Epstein's brother and next of kin.
Lt. M was on duty at the MCC at the time Jeffrey Epstein's body was found and was interviewed as a key witness.

events.title: Planned submission of redactions to OCME
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office plans to provide their proposed redactions for the Epstein autopsy report to the OCME.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found dead in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC); the OCME concluded the cause of death was suicide.

locations: Office of the Chief Medical Examiner (OCME)
keyFacts: The Office of the Chief Medical Examiner (OCME) completed a full autopsy report on Jeffrey Epstein, concluding his death was a suicide.

The U.S. Attorney's Office requested redactions to the autopsy report before its release to Mark Epstein to protect sensitive investigation details, including the names of prison guards under investigation and a draft FBI 302 of an interview with a key witness, Lt. M.
A handwritten note found in Epstein's cell was referenced in the report; it was described as a list of grievances about MCC conditions and was assessed not to be a suicide note.
